items.content_html:
Working on documenting the Trusted Types API. This PR adds:

  • TrustedHTML
  • TrustedScript
  • TrustedScriptURL

Spec: https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-trusted-types/dist/spec/

Reviewer: @jpmedley

To save yourself some time Joe, these are all pretty much the same as each other so if you want to snag TrustedHTML and the two method pages, I will then apply any changes to the others.

Also, it looks as if toJSON() is only in Canary (I tested it), and we have no BCD for the method. So that will need adding, which I can do if it is going to land.
items.title: Adds TrustedHTML, TrustedScript, TrustedScriptURL

items.content_html:
Checklist — To help your pull request get merged faster, please do following:

    • Provide a summary of your changes — say what problem you are fixing, what files are changed, what you've done. This doesn't need to be hugely detailed, as we can see exact changes in the "Files changed" tab.
    • Provide a link to the issue(s) you are fixing, if appropriate, in the form "Fixes url-of-issue". GitHub will render this in the form "Fixes #1234", with the issue number linked to the issue. Doing this allows us to figure out what issues you are fixing, as well as helping to automate things (for example the issue will be closed once the PR that fixed it has been merged).
    • Review the results of the automated checking we run on every PR and fix any problems reported (see the list of checks near the bottom of the PR page). If you need help, please ask in a comment!
    • Link to any other resources that you think might be useful in reviewing your PR.
items.title: Add a case to the warning

items.content_html:
1. Firefox 87 caps Mac OS X version at 10.15. This change was made in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1679929 to work around webcompat problems from websites that broke when the User-Agent string reported "Mac OS X 11.0". Safari also caps the reported Mac OS X version at 10.15 and Chrome plans to cap soon, too.
  2. Firefox no longer supports PPC Mac OS X, so remove mention of PPC Mac OS X.
items.title: Update Firefox User-Agent string reference for Mac OS X

items.content_html:
This adds back information about firefox preferences that can be used to set the default referrer-policy, which were removed in #2792. It contributes to #2516

My intent was to include this information in the BCD (mdn/browser-compat-data#9303). However the position taken is that these preferences are not "compatibility information" and shouldn't be in BCD. If you agree with that position it isn't clear where the information should go.

@chrisdavidmills What I have done is put this in its own section Firefox preferences. That removes it from the BCD and makes it very clear that this is Firefox only. I am not particularly happy with this, but I don't want to throw away the information about there is no better place for it (?). Perhaps we could make this section "Browser preferences" and then anyone who wants to add info about other browsers could do so?

Anyway, I consider this "open for discussion"
items.title: Add information about firefox default preferences

items.content_html:
This PR adds shared processes for triaging bugs, and running larger projects, for the benefits of teams in different orgs working together on mdn

Checklist — To help your pull request get merged faster, please do following:

    • Provide a summary of your changes — say what problem you are fixing, what files are changed, what you've done. This doesn't need to be hugely detailed, as we can see exact changes in the "Files changed" tab.
    • Provide a link to the issue(s) you are fixing, if appropriate, in the form "Fixes url-of-issue". GitHub will render this in the form "Fixes #1234", with the issue number linked to the issue. Doing this allows us to figure out what issues you are fixing, as well as helping to automate things (for example the issue will be closed once the PR that fixed it has been merged).
    • Review the results of the automated checking we run on every PR and fix any problems reported (see the list of checks near the bottom of the PR page). If you need help, please ask in a comment!
    • Link to any other resources that you think might be useful in reviewing your PR.
items.title: adding shared processes

items.content_html:
As part of adding our collaborative shared process to MDN, I've created this document to explain what docs are tier 1 and what are tier 2 on MDN. This will be useful during bug triage, and in future bits of work such as decide what content to convert to markdown first.

I made up some of the prioritization here, based on what docs seem most important. For the WebAPI prioritization, I followed @wbamberg 's excellent work in mdn/sprints#3327

Checklist — To help your pull request get merged faster, please do following:

    • Provide a summary of your changes — say what problem you are fixing, what files are changed, what you've done. This doesn't need to be hugely detailed, as we can see exact changes in the "Files changed" tab.
    • Provide a link to the issue(s) you are fixing, if appropriate, in the form "Fixes ". GitHub will render this in the form "Fixes #1234", with the issue number linked to the issue. Doing this allows us to figure out what issues you are fixing, as well as helping to automate things (for example the issue will be closed once the PR that fixed it has been merged).
    • Review the results of the automated checking we run on every PR and fix any problems reported (see the list of checks near the bottom of the PR page). If you need help, please ask in a comment!
    • Link to any other resources that you think might be useful in reviewing your PR.

items.content_html:
Fixes #2555
Fixes #2836

The authentication code relies on an OS import, which this adds into instructions. Note that the module is imported in the deployment module too which occurs later. I have made a conscious decision NOT to change that doc - multiple imports of that same module will do not harm to the tutorial, and this simplifies the instructions.

items.content_html:
Updates the list of properties that are forced.

Adds guidance around system color usage and the fact that they are respected in forced colors mode.

Explains that forced colors are chosen based on element, not role.

Adds an example of using a system color (previous example wouldn't have worked without forced-color-adjust: none).
items.title: Update documentation for forced colors mode
